docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore attacked Gov. George W. Bush on health care policy yesterday, using a telephone interview to reiterate his own proposals in detail and to mock his opponent's positions as lacking ''a minimal standard of substance for serious debate.'' Mr. Gore's comments came on a day when each campaign dispatched a surrogate to attack the other's positions on health policy, and when Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, acknowledged in two television interviews that Mr. Bush did not yet have a detailed plan for financing a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. Providing such a benefit under Medicare, at a cost estimated at $253 billion over 10 years, is a centerpiece of Mr. Gore's platform.

headline.main: Gore, Sensing Edge, Pushes Bush For More Specifics on Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Just five years ago, this small city on the Hudson River was literally broke. It had racked up millions of dollars of debts, but had scarcely enough money in the bank to cover a week's bills. It could put only two police cars out on the streets to patrol a city of 51,000 people. And city officials were scrambling to sell anything they could lay their hands on, up to and including City Hall, which at one point bore a sign reading ''For Sale by Owner.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert did not have to travel to Los Angeles to find a working poor family in the grip of stifling poverty (column, Aug. 21). Walk into any homeless shelter here in New York City, and you'll find men and women working at low-wage jobs, unable to afford rents in this booming economy. Walk into a city hospital's emergency room, and you'll see working families without health insurance relying on the hospital for their primary care.

docs.lead_paragraph: I COULD have taken my dirty clothes to a half-dozen closer laundries, but Chow and Lam Laundry was worth the extra two-block schlep. The other places folded with careless abandon, leaving a tangle of unmatched socks at the bottom of your laundry bag. Not Mimi and Peter Chow. Sheets were folded so crisply, like linen origami, it felt shameful to use them. My laundry bag, dropped off as an unwieldy blob, came back a perfect square.

docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT GALIONE'S lifelong passion is fighting fires. A New York City firefighter for more than 20 years, he joined the Lakeland Fire Department in 1985, serving as a volunteer firefighter and later as commissioner. On top of working nearly 50 hours a week at a Brooklyn rescue company, Mr. Galione, a 44-year-old father of three, spent 30 hours a week at the firehouse in Ronkonkoma. ''I would sit down to eat dinner with my family and at least two or three times a week, the alarm would go off, and by the time I would come back, no one was at the table and my dinner was cold,'' he said. ''You have to hope people in your life understand.''

docs.lead_paragraph: On the bus the other day, I glanced at the woman next to me. She was working on a special-education student's evaluation form, showing the child's name, the school's name and all of the child's problems and diagnoses. She should not have been doing confidential work in a public place. Should I call the school and tell them without mentioning the therapist's name or chalk it up to a momentary lapse in professional judgment? -- C. Cohen, Forest Hills, N.Y. Alas, I think the lapse is yours for the (admittedly minor) offense of snooping. A ''glance,'' as you call it, would not have revealed as much information as you took in. Give this poor, hard-working special-ed teacher a break; let her catch up on her work on the bus. It seems very unlikely that any misuse of the information could come from her fellow passengers. And with all due respect, for civil society to be possible, there are times when we each must mind our own business. (If, however, you'd like to do some glancing on that commuter spy bus that runs through Los Alamos, you might qualify for a part-time job with the F.B.I.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Riding a wave of success on his prescription-drug plan, Vice President Al Gore plans to dedicate all of next week to a cross-country discussion of health care issues and a comparison of his proposals with those of Gov. George W. Bush. Mr. Gore's advisers, who outlined the strategy in a conference call this morning, said that prescription drugs had emerged as the ''top issue,'' and that Mr. Gore had surged in the polls in part because he had dedicated so much time to the issue. The Republicans are clearly nervous about the inroads Mr. Gore has made with discussion of his plan and are running $7 million worth of television commercials criticizing the plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: The scene from the 1998 race for governor hardly suggested a typical Republican tableau: There in Segundo Barrio, one of the oldest and poorest neighborhoods in this isolated border city, Gov. George W. Bush had come to eat Mexican sweetbread and campaign in Spanish accented with a Texas twang. Mr. Bush was venturing into one of the last Democratic strongholds in Texas, an overwhelmingly Hispanic city that no Republican candidate for governor had ever won. But when Mr. Bush was re-elected by a landslide, he also by one estimate won nearly half the Hispanic vote statewide. He even won El Paso. It seemed like political magic; he had found votes in places Republicans usually dared not tread.
